newsitem.title: USA: May NAPM rise hints at brisk economic growth - Ore.
newsitem.headline: May NAPM rise hints at brisk economic growth - Ore.

text.p: A sharp rise in the National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM) index shows the U.S. economy grew at a brisk pace in May, a top NAPM offical said on Monday.

"(The rise in the NAPM index) certaintly indicates a good bit of growth in the economy in the month of May," Norbert Ore, who chairs the NAPM business survey committee, told reporters in a teleconference.
Earlier on Monday, the NAPM said its May Purchasing Management Index rose to 57.1 from 54.2 in April.
Ore said a strong jump in the new orders component of the index to 64.2 in May against a 57.9 reading in April suggested that manufacturing growth might continue in the near future.
"New orders always leads production, so it should indicate that the (industry) growth would continue," Ore said.
The official said the rise in the May NAPM index, the highest since November 1994, was not seen as a one-time jump but as an indication of sustained economic growth.
"(The rise in the May index) is not necessarily an aberration ... I think it's just an indication of good sustained growth," Ore said.
Ore said there was widespread expectations among purchasing managers that prices would not rise in the near future, adding that he see did not see a lot of inflation signs on the horizon.
He also said manufacturing employment was expected to continue to grow despite a slight drop in May. The employment component of the NAPM index fell to 52.6 in May from 52.8 in April.
